entry.et: Middle English adressen, from Anglo-French adrescer, from a- (from Latin ad-) + drescer to direct, put right dress

def.dt: :direct aim
:to direct to go :send
:to direct the efforts or attention of (oneself) will address himself to the problem
:to deal with :treat intrigued by the chance to address important issues I. L. Horowitz
:to make ready
:dress
:to communicate directly addresses his thanks to his host
:to speak or write directly to
:to deliver a formal speech to
:to mark directions for delivery on address a letter
:to consign to the care of another (as an agent or factor)
:to greet by a prescribed form
:to adjust the club preparatory to hitting (a golf ball)
:to identify (as a computer peripheral or memory location) by an address or a name for information transfer
:to direct one's speech or attentions
:dutiful and courteous attention especially in courtship usually used in plural
:readiness and capability for dealing (as with a person or problem) skillfully and smoothly :adroitness
:a making ready
:a state of preparedness
:manner of bearing oneself a man of rude address
:manner of speaking or singing :delivery
:a formal communication
:a prepared speech delivered to a special audience or on a special occasion
:a place where a person or organization may be communicated with
:directions for delivery on the outside of an object (as a letter or package)
:the designation of place of delivery placed between the heading and salutation on a business letter
:the designation of a computer account from which one can send or receive e-mail
:a preparatory position of the player and club in golf
:a location (as in the memory of a computer) where particular information is stored
:a series of usually alphanumeric characters that specifies the storage location (as on a network or in a computer's memory) of particular information an Internet address
:address 5c
:the numeric address of a computer on the Internet
:an address designed to present the issues of primary interest to an assembly (as a political convention) and often to arouse unity and enthusiasm called also keynote speech
:an apparatus including a microphone and loudspeakers used for broadcasting (as to an audience in an auditorium)
